<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para.0055" view="all">A two-dimensional polynuclear complex [Ni(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-mpyo)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (where mpyo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-methylpyridine N-oxide) has been synthesized and its crystal structure determined by X-ray crystallography. In the complex there exist two kinds of bridging ligands, namely, μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligand and μ-mpyo bridging ligand. The two kinds of bridging ligands coordinate to Ni(II) ions in alternate fashion and it led to the formation of a two-dimensional sheet. The density functional calculations have been carried out on the binuclear model complexes to analyze the magnetic coupling mechanisms. The variable temperature (4–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) magnetic measurements were performed and the experimental data were fitted by using a binuclear Ni(II) magnetic coupling formula. The magnetic coupling constants from calculations are <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−61.81<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for μ-mpyo bridging ligand and <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−13.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligand, and the experimental value is <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−36.22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A two-dimensional polynuclear complex [Ni(μ1,3-SCN)2(μ-mpyo)] n  (where mpyo=4-methylpyridine N-oxide) has been synthesized and its crystal structure determined by X-ray crystallography. In the complex there exist two kinds of bridging ligands, namely, μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand and μ-mpyo bridging ligand. The two kinds of bridging ligands coordinate to Ni(II) ions in alternate fashion and it led to the formation of a two-dimensional sheet. The density functional calculations have been carried out on the binuclear model complexes to analyze the magnetic coupling mechanisms. The variable temperature (4-300K) magnetic measurements were performed and the experimental data were fitted by using a binuclear Ni(II) magnetic coupling formula. The magnetic coupling constants from calculations are J =-61.81cm-1 for μ-mpyo bridging ligand and J =-13.31cm-1 for μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand, and the experimental value is J =-36.22cm-1. In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0010" view="all">Recently, the field of molecular magnetism has attracted considerable attention, and major advances have been made in both their theoretical description and their application as new molecular-based materials . It is a very interesting and important work to make the magneto-structure studies and especially using calculation method to elucidate the magneto-structure correlations. In this area much work has been made in the multi-nuclear complexes with μ-azido , μ-hydroxyl , μ-halide , etc.  as bridged ligands, and by contrast, as we know, only one example deals with the thiocyanate bridging binuclear copper(II) complex  and one paper is available for the binuclear Cu(II) complex  with pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands, and no paper has been published for complexes with mixed bridging ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, the field of molecular magnetism has attracted considerable attention, and major advances have been made in both their theoretical description and their application as new molecular-based materials . It is a very interesting and important work to make the magneto-structure studies and especially using calculation method to elucidate the magneto-structure correlations. In this area much work has been made in the multi-nuclear complexes with μ-azido , μ-hydroxyl , μ-halide , etc.  as bridged ligands, and by contrast, as we know, only one example deals with the thiocyanate bridging binuclear copper(II) complex  and one paper is available for the binuclear Cu(II) complex  with pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands, and no paper has been published for complexes with mixed bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para.0015" view="all">The thiocyanate anion, which exhibited ambidentate character of end-to-end or end-on coordination modes , is expected to play a key role in the design of poly-metallic coupling system. A certain number of poly-nuclear complexes have been synthesized with one-, two- and three-dimensional crystal structures and some of them exhibit interesting magnetic coupling properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thiocyanate anion, which exhibited ambidentate character of end-to-end or end-on coordination modes , is expected to play a key role in the design of poly-metallic coupling system. A certain number of poly-nuclear complexes have been synthesized with one-, two- and three-dimensional crystal structures and some of them exhibit interesting magnetic coupling properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para.0020" view="all">In order to obtain strong magnetic interaction judicious choice of coordinated atoms with larger electronic densities is a crucial factor. The theoretical calculations have confirmed that the O atoms from pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives display electron-rich densities than that of N atom of pyridine and its derivatives , and some binuclear Cu(II) complexes  with pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands display very strong magnetic interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to obtain strong magnetic interaction judicious choice of coordinated atoms with larger electronic densities is a crucial factor. The theoretical calculations have confirmed that the O atoms from pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives display electron-rich densities than that of N atom of pyridine and its derivatives , and some binuclear Cu(II) complexes  with pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands display very strong magnetic interactions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para.0025" view="all">Interesting in the magneto-structure studies of multi-nuclear complexes with thiocyanate anion, pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands resulted in synthesis, characterization and magnetic study of title complex. In this paper we present the crystal structure and the magnetic behaviors from both the experimental values and the theoretical calculations for the title complex. This is the first paper that deals with magneto-structure study using theoretical calculation for the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Interesting in the magneto-structure studies of multi-nuclear complexes with thiocyanate anion, pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as bridging ligands resulted in synthesis, characterization and magnetic study of title complex. In this paper we present the crystal structure and the magnetic behaviors from both the experimental values and the theoretical calculations for the title complex. This is the first paper that deals with magneto-structure study using theoretical calculation for the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All chemicals are analytical grade and used without further purification.

Preparation of [Ni(μ1,3-SCN)2(μ-MPyO)2] n  

Ni(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.3240g, 8.86×10-4 mol), NaSCN (0.1437g, 1.77×10-3 mol) and 4-methylpyridine N-oxide (0.1934g, 1.77×10-3 mol) were each dissolved in 10mL of methanol and then the three kinds of solution were mixed together. The yellowish single crystals were obtained after the mixed solution was allowed to stand slow evaporation for two weeks at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Anal. Calcd (found) for C8H7N3NiOS2 (Fw: 283.995): C, 33.83(34.15); H, 2.48(2.75); N, 14.80(14.37); Ni, 20.67(19.98). IR(cm-1): 2124 s, 1625 m, 1499 m, 1401 m, 1209 m, 829 m, 762 m.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0040" view="all">Infrared spectra were recorded with a Bruker Tensor 27 infrared spectrometer in the 4000–500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region using KBr discs. C, H and N elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240 instrument. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of microcrystalline powder samples were measured in a magnetic fields of 10 KOe in the temperature range of 4–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a SQUID magnetometer. The data were corrected for magnetisation of the sample holder and for diamagnetic contributions which were estimated from Pascal’s constants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

Infrared spectra were recorded with a Bruker Tensor 27 infrared spectrometer in the 4000-500cm-1 region using KBr discs. C, H and N elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240 instrument. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of microcrystalline powder samples were measured in a magnetic fields of 10 KOe in the temperature range of 4-300K on a SQUID magnetometer. The data were corrected for magnetisation of the sample holder and for diamagnetic contributions which were estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Density function calculation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0045" view="all">All the calculations have been performed using Amsterdam density functional (ADF) package (version 2.0.1). Vosko, Wilk and Nusair’s (VWN) function was used for local spin density approximation (LSDA) . Generalized gradient correlations have been introduced by using the Becke exchange function  and the Perdew correlation function . IV basis sets in ADF containing triple-<ce:italic>ζ</ce:italic> basis sets and a polarization function from H to Ar were used for all atoms in the systems. The frozen core (FC) approximation for the inner core electrons was employed. The orbitals up to 2p for S, Ni and 1s for C, N, O atoms were kept frozen. The numerical integration procedure applied for the calculation is polyhedron method developed by Velde and co-worker . All the calculations were done on an SGI O2100 server.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Density function calculation

All the calculations have been performed using Amsterdam density functional (ADF) package (version 2.0.1). Vosko, Wilk and Nusair's (VWN) function was used for local spin density approximation (LSDA) . Generalized gradient correlations have been introduced by using the Becke exchange function  and the Perdew correlation function . IV basis sets in ADF containing triple-ζ basis sets and a polarization function from H to Ar were used for all atoms in the systems. The frozen core (FC) approximation for the inner core electrons was employed. The orbitals up to 2p for S, Ni and 1s for C, N, O atoms were kept frozen. The numerical integration procedure applied for the calculation is polyhedron method developed by Velde and co-worker . All the calculations were done on an SGI O2100 server.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic analysis of the complex

A single crystal of dimensions 0.15×0.12×0.11mm was selected and subsequently glued to the tip of a glass fiber. The determination of the crystal structure at 20°C was carried out on an X-ray diffractometer, Model Bruker Smart-1000 CCD using graphite-monochromatic Mokα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Corrections for Lp factors were applied and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and included in the final cycles of refinement using a riding model. The programs for structure solution and refinement were SHELXS-97 (Sheldrick, 1990) and SHELXL-97 (Sheldrick, 1997), respectively. The crystal belongs to triclinic, space group   P   1   ¯     with a =7.888(2) Å, b =8.103(2) Å, c =9.590(2) Å, α =71.950(3)°, β =77.227(4)°, γ =71.760(3)°, V =548.3(2) Å3, empirical formula C8H7N3NiOS2, molecular weight 283.995, D  c  =1.720g/cm3, F(000)=288, θ range 2.26-25.00°, index ranges -9⩽ h ⩽9, -9⩽ k ⩽9, -6⩽ l ⩽11. A total of 2814 reflections were collected and 1886 were independent (R int =0.0200), of which 1629 observed reflections with I >2σ(I) were used in the succeeding refinement. The final refinement including hydrogen atoms converged to R =0.0359, wR =0.0819, (Δρ)max =0.374e/Å3, (Δρ)min =-0.295e/Å3. The deposition number of the crystal at the CCDC is 260644.

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [Ni(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ-MPyO)]<ce:inf loc="post">

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0055" view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the coordination diagram with atom numbering scheme. The coordination sphere around Ni1 atom displays a octahedral geometry and is completed by O1, O1A, N3, N2A, S1 and S2A atoms, in which O1 and O1A come from two mono-dentate bridging ligands μ-mpyo molecules, other four atoms are from four μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligands, respectively, and the data from 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor> further confirm that Ni1 atom lies in a distorted octahedron environment. In the crystal there exist two kinds of bridging ligands, namely, μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligand and μ-mpyo bridging ligand, and each Ni(II) ion is connected with the three adjacent Ni(II) ions by two μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligands or by two μ-mpyo bridging ligands. Two μ-mpyo bridging ligands coordinate to two adjacent Ni(II) ions and which forms a binuclear unit with a Ni⋯Ni separation of 3.383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the four atoms are strictly located on a plane. Two μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligands join two neighbor Ni(II) ions with the separation distance 5.634<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å into a 8-membered ring and the atoms of the 8-membered ring define a plane within 0.0711<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with maximum deviation of 0.1030<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for atom N3. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor> shows that a 34-membered ring is fabricated by eight μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligands, four μ-mpyo mono-dentate bridging ligands and six Ni(II) ions, and in the ring the maximum distance between the Ni(II) ions is about 10.140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the rings as subunits are further assembled into a 2D sheet that is located on <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of [Ni(μ1,3-SCN)3(μ-MPyO)] n  

   shows the coordination diagram with atom numbering scheme. The coordination sphere around Ni1 atom displays a octahedral geometry and is completed by O1, O1A, N3, N2A, S1 and S2A atoms, in which O1 and O1A come from two mono-dentate bridging ligands μ-mpyo molecules, other four atoms are from four μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligands, respectively, and the data from   further confirm that Ni1 atom lies in a distorted octahedron environment. In the crystal there exist two kinds of bridging ligands, namely, μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand and μ-mpyo bridging ligand, and each Ni(II) ion is connected with the three adjacent Ni(II) ions by two μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligands or by two μ-mpyo bridging ligands. Two μ-mpyo bridging ligands coordinate to two adjacent Ni(II) ions and which forms a binuclear unit with a Ni⋯Ni separation of 3.383Å, and the four atoms are strictly located on a plane. Two μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligands join two neighbor Ni(II) ions with the separation distance 5.634Å into a 8-membered ring and the atoms of the 8-membered ring define a plane within 0.0711Å with maximum deviation of 0.1030Å for atom N3.   shows that a 34-membered ring is fabricated by eight μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligands, four μ-mpyo mono-dentate bridging ligands and six Ni(II) ions, and in the ring the maximum distance between the Ni(II) ions is about 10.140Å and the rings as subunits are further assembled into a 2D sheet that is located on ab plane.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Theoretical study on magnetic interaction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0060" view="all">In this complex there exist two pathways that may lead to the magnetic interactions between the bridged Ni(II) ions, namely, the magnetic coupling can be mediated by mono-dentate μ-mpyo bridging ligands or by μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligands. In order to understand which pathway is most effective density function calculations were performed on the binuclear model complexes [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] as shown in

elements.clean_text:
Theoretical study on magnetic interaction

In this complex there exist two pathways that may lead to the magnetic interactions between the bridged Ni(II) ions, namely, the magnetic coupling can be mediated by mono-dentate μ-mpyo bridging ligands or by μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligands. In order to understand which pathway is most effective density function calculations were performed on the binuclear model complexes [Ni2(μ-mpyo)2(SCN)4(NH3)2] and [Ni2(μ1,3-SCN)2(mpyo)4(SCN)2(NH3)2] as shown in   , respectively, and the calculation was constrained by the data of the bond lengths and the angles which are from the X-ray structures of the present complex. The calculations are based on Noodelnann's suggestions  and the model of binuclear Ni(II) Hamiltonians, namely,     H   ˆ   = - 2 J     S   ˆ     1       S   ˆ     2    , in which       S   ˆ     1     and       S   ˆ     2     stand for spin operator of Ni(II) ion, and       S   ˆ     1   =     S   ˆ     2   = 2 / 2  . It means that the magnetic coupling constants for binuclear Ni(II) system can be obtained using the expression E(QS)- E(BS)=-4J, where E(QS) and E(BS) represent the energies of the quintet and broken-symmetry states, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para.0065" view="all">The calculations give the coupling constants <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−61.81<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the model complex [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−13.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the model complex [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. It means that there exists a moderate magnetic interaction between μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions, whereas the magnetic coupling through μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligand is relatively weak. The stronger magnetic coupling may be attributed to the shorter distance between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions and the fact that the two Ni(II) ions and two bridging oxygen atom are strictly located on a plane. The calculations also indicate that the anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbital of the bridging O atoms, and the weak anti-ferromagnetic interaction between μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>-bridged Ni(II) is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbitals of the bridging N and S atoms. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor> show the calculated spin density distribution of the broken-symmetry states for some atoms of the two model complexes. From crystal structure we know that each Ni(II) ion involves two unpaired electrons which are located on the d orbital. However,  displays that the spin populations on the atom Ni1 and Ni1A are less than 2, which implies that there is a moderate spin delocalization on atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A and there exists the magnetic interaction between bridging atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A. It is worthy noticing from  that the spin density on the bridging atom O1 or atom O1A is very small and belongs to α spin. The Ni(II) ions on the broken-symmetry state possess both α spin electron and β spin electron, and these electrons are delocalized to the bridging O atoms and it made the offset of the α spin electron and β spin electron on the O atoms, and so the bridging O atoms exhibit the very small spin density.  also provides the same information as . But compared with the absolute values of the spin densities on the Ni atoms it is known that the spin density of atom Ni1 from  is smaller than that of atom Ni1 from , and the spin density of atom Ni1A from  is also smaller than that of atom Ni1A from . The smaller spin density means the larger electron delocalization, and the larger delocalization implies the stronger anti-ferromagnetic coupling, namely, the magnetic interaction from μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is strong than that from the μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>-bridged Ni(II) ions, which is consistent with the calculated <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> values mentioned above.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Experimental results

The variable temperature (4-300K) magnetic susceptibility measurements were made and the experimental results are shown in  , where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per binuclear Ni(II) unit, and μeff is magnetic moment for binuclear Ni(II) ions and the data have been corrected for diamagnetism.  displays that the χ M values increases with decreasing temperature and it reaches a maximum at T N =111.43K, and then it follows a sharp decrease. The μeff value at 300K is 3.88 BM which is slightly smaller than that of expected value for an isolated binuclear nickel(II) (4.00 μB for g av =2) at room temperature, and the μeff value decreases with temperature drop and it reaches a minimum 0.28 BM at 5.04K, which implies a anti-ferromagnetic exchange between the bridged Ni(II) ions. Because no formula is available for two-dimensional Ni(II) complex, and from the information of the calculations above it is known that the magnetic coupling of the complex is mainly through the μ-mpyo bridging ligand, so binuclear Ni(II) formula is used to fit the experimental data. Eq.  was obtained based on an isotropic Hamiltonian presented as in Eq.  with the magnetic interaction of binuclear bridging Ni(II) ions.  (1)    H   ˆ   = - 2 J     S   ˆ     1       S   ˆ     2   ,      (2)    χ   M   = [ 2   Ng   2     β   2   / κ ( T - θ ) ] [ A / B ] ,            A = 5 + exp ( - 4 J / κ T ) ,        B = 5 + 3 exp ( - 4 J / κ T ) + exp ( - 6 J / κ T ) ,       where J is the Heisenberg exchange constant between the μ-mpyo bridged Ni(II) ions,       S   ˆ     1     and       S   ˆ     2     (      S   ˆ     1   =     S   ˆ     2   = 2 / 2  ) are spin operators corresponding to Ni(II), θ is the magnetic interaction between the non-bridged Ni(II) ions. The theoretical model gave a good fitting with the experimental date except below 18K, and the larger deviation below 18K may be from the strong zero-field splitting. The agreement factor R =6.6×10-3 [R is defined as R = Σ (χ obsd. - χ Calcd.)2/(χ obsd.)2], g =2.24 and J =-36.22cm-1, θ =-0.08cm-1. The J value again confirms the moderate anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the bridged Ni(II) ions. It is known that absolute value of calculation J =-61.81cm-1 is larger than that of experimental value J =-36.22cm-1, which may arise from the fact that the function employed in DFT computation may have a bit of overestimate to the stability of the broken-symmetry state and which led to the relatively large J value. In addition, the experimental J value is from a binuclear model, whereas the true structure is a two-dimensional structure and which may bring about some error. In fact, the orders of the magnitude of both the calculated J value and the experimental one are in agreement with each other and it is very normal that there is a certain error between calculation value and experimental value . In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para.0075" view="all">In this work, a two-dimensional polynuclear Ni(II) complex has been synthesized with thiocyanate and 4-methylpyridine N-oxide as mixed bridging ligands, and its crystal structure determined. The theoretical calculations reveal that the there exist a moderate anti-ferromagnetic coupling between μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions and a weak anti-ferromagnetic interaction between μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging Ni(II) ions. The experimental results confirm that there exists a moderate anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the bridging Ni(II) ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, a two-dimensional polynuclear Ni(II) complex has been synthesized with thiocyanate and 4-methylpyridine N-oxide as mixed bridging ligands, and its crystal structure determined. The theoretical calculations reveal that the there exist a moderate anti-ferromagnetic coupling between μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions and a weak anti-ferromagnetic interaction between μ1,3-SCN- bridging Ni(II) ions. The experimental results confirm that there exists a moderate anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the bridging Ni(II) ions.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All chemicals are analytical grade and used without further purification.

Preparation of [Ni(μ1,3-SCN)2(μ-MPyO)2] n  

Ni(ClO4)2 ⋅6H2O (0.3240g, 8.86×10-4 mol), NaSCN (0.1437g, 1.77×10-3 mol) and 4-methylpyridine N-oxide (0.1934g, 1.77×10-3 mol) were each dissolved in 10mL of methanol and then the three kinds of solution were mixed together. The yellowish single crystals were obtained after the mixed solution was allowed to stand slow evaporation for two weeks at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Anal. Calcd (found) for C8H7N3NiOS2 (Fw: 283.995): C, 33.83(34.15); H, 2.48(2.75); N, 14.80(14.37); Ni, 20.67(19.98). IR(cm-1): 2124 s, 1625 m, 1499 m, 1401 m, 1209 m, 829 m, 762 m.

X-ray crystallographic analysis of the complex

A single crystal of dimensions 0.15×0.12×0.11mm was selected and subsequently glued to the tip of a glass fiber. The determination of the crystal structure at 20°C was carried out on an X-ray diffractometer, Model Bruker Smart-1000 CCD using graphite-monochromatic Mokα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Corrections for Lp factors were applied and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and included in the final cycles of refinement using a riding model. The programs for structure solution and refinement were SHELXS-97 (Sheldrick, 1990) and SHELXL-97 (Sheldrick, 1997), respectively. The crystal belongs to triclinic, space group   P   1   ¯     with a =7.888(2) Å, b =8.103(2) Å, c =9.590(2) Å, α =71.950(3)°, β =77.227(4)°, γ =71.760(3)°, V =548.3(2) Å3, empirical formula C8H7N3NiOS2, molecular weight 283.995, D  c  =1.720g/cm3, F(000)=288, θ range 2.26-25.00°, index ranges -9⩽ h ⩽9, -9⩽ k ⩽9, -6⩽ l ⩽11. A total of 2814 reflections were collected and 1886 were independent (R int =0.0200), of which 1629 observed reflections with I >2σ(I) were used in the succeeding refinement. The final refinement including hydrogen atoms converged to R =0.0359, wR =0.0819, (Δρ)max =0.374e/Å3, (Δρ)min =-0.295e/Å3. The deposition number of the crystal at the CCDC is 260644.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−36.22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="para.0065" view="all">The calculations give the coupling constants <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−61.81<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the model complex [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−13.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the model complex [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mpyo)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. It means that there exists a moderate magnetic interaction between μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions, whereas the magnetic coupling through μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridging ligand is relatively weak. The stronger magnetic coupling may be attributed to the shorter distance between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions and the fact that the two Ni(II) ions and two bridging oxygen atom are strictly located on a plane. The calculations also indicate that the anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbital of the bridging O atoms, and the weak anti-ferromagnetic interaction between μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>-bridged Ni(II) is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbitals of the bridging N and S atoms. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor> show the calculated spin density distribution of the broken-symmetry states for some atoms of the two model complexes. From crystal structure we know that each Ni(II) ion involves two unpaired electrons which are located on the d orbital. However,  displays that the spin populations on the atom Ni1 and Ni1A are less than 2, which implies that there is a moderate spin delocalization on atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A and there exists the magnetic interaction between bridging atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A. It is worthy noticing from  that the spin density on the bridging atom O1 or atom O1A is very small and belongs to α spin. The Ni(II) ions on the broken-symmetry state possess both α spin electron and β spin electron, and these electrons are delocalized to the bridging O atoms and it made the offset of the α spin electron and β spin electron on the O atoms, and so the bridging O atoms exhibit the very small spin density.  also provides the same information as . But compared with the absolute values of the spin densities on the Ni atoms it is known that the spin density of atom Ni1 from  is smaller than that of atom Ni1 from , and the spin density of atom Ni1A from  is also smaller than that of atom Ni1A from . The smaller spin density means the larger electron delocalization, and the larger delocalization implies the stronger anti-ferromagnetic coupling, namely, the magnetic interaction from μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is strong than that from the μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>-bridged Ni(II) ions, which is consistent with the calculated <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> values mentioned above.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A two-dimensional polynuclear complex [Ni(μ1,3-SCN)2(μ-mpyo)] n  (where mpyo=4-methylpyridine N-oxide) has been synthesized and its crystal structure determined by X-ray crystallography. In the complex there exist two kinds of bridging ligands, namely, μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand and μ-mpyo bridging ligand. The two kinds of bridging ligands coordinate to Ni(II) ions in alternate fashion and it led to the formation of a two-dimensional sheet. The density functional calculations have been carried out on the binuclear model complexes to analyze the magnetic coupling mechanisms. The variable temperature (4-300K) magnetic measurements were performed and the experimental data were fitted by using a binuclear Ni(II) magnetic coupling formula. The magnetic coupling constants from calculations are J =-61.81cm-1 for μ-mpyo bridging ligand and J =-13.31cm-1 for μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand, and the experimental value is J =-36.22cm-1. In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.

The calculations give the coupling constants J =-61.81cm-1 for the model complex [Ni2(μ-mpyo)2(SCN)4(NH3)2] and J =-13.31cm-1 for the model complex [Ni2(μ1,3-SCN)2(mpyo)4(SCN)2(NH3)2]. It means that there exists a moderate magnetic interaction between μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions, whereas the magnetic coupling through μ1,3-SCN- bridging ligand is relatively weak. The stronger magnetic coupling may be attributed to the shorter distance between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions and the fact that the two Ni(II) ions and two bridging oxygen atom are strictly located on a plane. The calculations also indicate that the anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbital of the bridging O atoms, and the weak anti-ferromagnetic interaction between μ1,3-SCN--bridged Ni(II) is due to the overlap of the Ni(II) d orbital with the p orbitals of the bridging N and S atoms.    show the calculated spin density distribution of the broken-symmetry states for some atoms of the two model complexes. From crystal structure we know that each Ni(II) ion involves two unpaired electrons which are located on the d orbital. However,  displays that the spin populations on the atom Ni1 and Ni1A are less than 2, which implies that there is a moderate spin delocalization on atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A and there exists the magnetic interaction between bridging atom Ni1 and atom Ni1A. It is worthy noticing from  that the spin density on the bridging atom O1 or atom O1A is very small and belongs to α spin. The Ni(II) ions on the broken-symmetry state possess both α spin electron and β spin electron, and these electrons are delocalized to the bridging O atoms and it made the offset of the α spin electron and β spin electron on the O atoms, and so the bridging O atoms exhibit the very small spin density.  also provides the same information as . But compared with the absolute values of the spin densities on the Ni atoms it is known that the spin density of atom Ni1 from  is smaller than that of atom Ni1 from , and the spin density of atom Ni1A from  is also smaller than that of atom Ni1A from . The smaller spin density means the larger electron delocalization, and the larger delocalization implies the stronger anti-ferromagnetic coupling, namely, the magnetic interaction from μ-mpyo-bridged Ni(II) ions is strong than that from the μ1,3-SCN--bridged Ni(II) ions, which is consistent with the calculated J values mentioned above.

The μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is 3.88 BM which is slightly smaller than that of expected value for an isolated binuclear nickel(II) (4.00 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) at room temperature, and the μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value decreases with temperature drop and it reaches a minimum 0.28 BM at 5.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which implies a anti-ferromagnetic exchange between the bridged Ni(II) ions. Because no formula is available for two-dimensional Ni(II) complex, and from the information of the calculations above it is known that the magnetic coupling of the complex is mainly through the μ-mpyo bridging ligand, so binuclear Ni(II) formula is used to fit the experimental data. Eq.  was obtained based on an isotropic Hamiltonian presented as in Eq.  with the magnetic interaction of binuclear bridging Ni(II) ions.<ce:display>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental results

The variable temperature (4-300K) magnetic susceptibility measurements were made and the experimental results are shown in  , where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility per binuclear Ni(II) unit, and μeff is magnetic moment for binuclear Ni(II) ions and the data have been corrected for diamagnetism.  displays that the χ M values increases with decreasing temperature and it reaches a maximum at T N =111.43K, and then it follows a sharp decrease. The μeff value at 300K is 3.88 BM which is slightly smaller than that of expected value for an isolated binuclear nickel(II) (4.00 μB for g av =2) at room temperature, and the μeff value decreases with temperature drop and it reaches a minimum 0.28 BM at 5.04K, which implies a anti-ferromagnetic exchange between the bridged Ni(II) ions. Because no formula is available for two-dimensional Ni(II) complex, and from the information of the calculations above it is known that the magnetic coupling of the complex is mainly through the μ-mpyo bridging ligand, so binuclear Ni(II) formula is used to fit the experimental data. Eq.  was obtained based on an isotropic Hamiltonian presented as in Eq.  with the magnetic interaction of binuclear bridging Ni(II) ions.  (1)    H   ˆ   = - 2 J     S   ˆ     1       S   ˆ     2   ,      (2)    χ   M   = [ 2   Ng   2     β   2   / κ ( T - θ ) ] [ A / B ] ,            A = 5 + exp ( - 4 J / κ T ) ,        B = 5 + 3 exp ( - 4 J / κ T ) + exp ( - 6 J / κ T ) ,       where J is the Heisenberg exchange constant between the μ-mpyo bridged Ni(II) ions,       S   ˆ     1     and       S   ˆ     2     (      S   ˆ     1   =     S   ˆ     2   = 2 / 2  ) are spin operators corresponding to Ni(II), θ is the magnetic interaction between the non-bridged Ni(II) ions. The theoretical model gave a good fitting with the experimental date except below 18K, and the larger deviation below 18K may be from the strong zero-field splitting. The agreement factor R =6.6×10-3 [R is defined as R = Σ (χ obsd. - χ Calcd.)2/(χ obsd.)2], g =2.24 and J =-36.22cm-1, θ =-0.08cm-1. The J value again confirms the moderate anti-ferromagnetic interaction between the bridged Ni(II) ions. It is known that absolute value of calculation J =-61.81cm-1 is larger than that of experimental value J =-36.22cm-1, which may arise from the fact that the function employed in DFT computation may have a bit of overestimate to the stability of the broken-symmetry state and which led to the relatively large J value. In addition, the experimental J value is from a binuclear model, whereas the true structure is a two-dimensional structure and which may bring about some error. In fact, the orders of the magnitude of both the calculated J value and the experimental one are in agreement with each other and it is very normal that there is a certain error between calculation value and experimental value . In the area of magneto-structure theoretical calculation study this is the first paper that deals with the complexes with mixed bridging ligands.
